enumerate:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\star$ is associative since $\mathrm{Diffops}(\mathbbm{R})$ is an
    associative algebra.
\item $f \star g = fg \; +$ higher orders in $\hbar$.
\item $f \star g - g \star f = {\mathrm i} \hbar \{f,g\} \; +$ 
    higher orders in $\hbar$.
\item $f \star 1 = f = 1 \star f$.
\item $f \star g = \sum_{r=0}^\infty \hbar^r C_r(f,g)$ with
    bidifferential operators $C_r$.
\

\begin{enumerate}
    \item $f \star g = fg + \cdots$,
    \item $f \star g - g \star f = {\mathrm i}\lambda\{f,g\} + \cdots$,
    \item $f \star 1 = f = 1 \star f$,
    \item $C_r$ is a bidifferential operator.
    \

\begin{enumerate}
    \item ${\left\langle{{\phi, z\psi + w \chi}}\right\rangle} = z {\left\langle{{\phi,\psi}}\right\rangle} + w
        {\left\langle{{\phi,\chi}}\right\rangle}$ for $\phi,\psi,\chi \in \mathcal{H}$ and $z,w
        \in {\mathsf{{C}}}$.
    \item ${\left\langle{{\phi,\psi}}\right\rangle} = \overline{{{\left\langle{{\psi,\phi}}\right\rangle}}}$ for $\phi, \psi \in
        \mathcal{H}$.
    \item ${\left\langle{{\phi,\phi}}\right\rangle} > 0$ for $\phi \ne 0$.
    \

\begin{enumerate}
    \item $A^*$ is unique and $A^* \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$,
        $A^{**} = A$.
    \item $zA +wB \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$ and $(zA+wB)^* =
        \overline{{z}}A^* + \overline{{w}} B^*$.
    \item $AB \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$ and $(AB)^* = B^*A^*$.
    \

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Any $C^*$-algebra is a $^*$-algebra over $\mathbbm{C}$.
    \item $(C^\infty(M)[[\lambda]], \star)$ with a Hermitian star
        product is a $^*$-algebra over $\mathbbm{C}[[\lambda]]$.
    \item $\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$ is a $^*$-algebra over ${\mathsf{{C}}}$
        for any pre Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$ over ${\mathsf{{C}}}$.
    \item If $\mathcal{A}$ is a $^*$-algebra then $M_n(\mathcal{A})$
        becomes a $^*$-algebra as well.
    \

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Let $\phi \in \mathcal{H}$ with ${\left\langle{{\phi,\phi}}\right\rangle} = 1$ and
        consider the positive functional $\omega(A) = {\left\langle{{\phi,A\phi}}\right\rangle}$
        on the $^*$-algebra $\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$. Then
        $\mathcal{J}_\omega = \{A \; | \; A\phi = 0\}$ whence
        \begin{equation}
            \label{eq:GNSREproduction}
            \mathcal{H}_\omega =
            \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})\big/\mathcal{J}_\omega \ni \psi_A
            \; \mapsto \; A\phi \in \mathcal{H}
        \end{equation}
        is a unitary isomorphism and in fact an intertwiner. Thus one
        recovers the usual action of $\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{H})$ on
        $\mathcal{H}$ by the GNS construction.
    \item Consider again the Schrödinger functional $\omega$ as in
        (\ref{eq:schroedinger}) which is positive for the Weyl star
        product. Then the GNS representation induced by this $\omega$
        is canonically unitarily equivalent to the usual (formal)
        Schrödinger representation in Weyl ordering $\varrho_{{\scriptscriptstyle\mathrm{Weyl}}}$ on the pre
        Hilbert space $C^\infty_0(\mathbbm{R}^n)[[\lambda]]$ of formal
        wave functions, see e.g. \cite{bordemann.waldmann:1998a}.
    \

\begin{enumerate}
\item There are analogues of $\star_{{\scriptscriptstyle\mathrm{S}}}$ and $\star_{{\scriptscriptstyle\mathrm{Weyl}}}$ for any cotangent
    bundle $T^*Q$ such that one has a Schrödinger representation on
    $C^\infty_0(Q)[[\lambda]]$ being the GNS representation for a
    Schrödinger functional consisting of integration over $Q$ with
    respect to some positive density
    \cite{bordemann.neumaier.waldmann:1999a}.
\item The WKB expansion \cite{bates.weinstein:1995a} can be obtained
    in a particular GNS representation where the positive functional
    is a particular integration over the graph of $dS$ in $T^*Q$ where
    $S: Q \to \mathbbm{R}$ is a solution of the Hamilton-Jacobi
    equation $H \circ dS = E$, see
    \cite{bordemann.neumaier.waldmann:1999a,bordemann.neumaier.pflaum.waldmann:1998a:pre}.
\item There is also a characterization of thermodynamical states using
    the KMS condition. It turns out that for a given inverse
    temperature $\beta$ and a Hamiltonian $H$ the KMS states are
    unique and of the form
    \begin{equation}
        \label{eq:KMS}
        \omega(f) = \mathop{{\mathsf{tr}}}\left(\mathrm{Exp}(-\beta H) \star f\right),
    \end{equation}
    where $\mathrm{Exp}$ is the star exponential and $\mathop{{\mathsf{tr}}}$ the unique
    trace for a symplectic star product. The GNS representation turns
    out to be faithful with commutant being (anti-) isomorphic to the
    algebra itself. This gives a sort of baby-version of the
    Tomita-Takesaki theorem
    \cite{basart.flato.lichnerowicz.sternheimer:1984a,bordemann.roemer.waldmann:1998a,waldmann:2000a}.
\
